p: Parkinson's disease (PD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) are the two most common age-related neurodegenerative diseases. PD is primarily a movement disorder, the characteristic motor features of which mainly result from loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta [ 1]. However, patients with PD may experience a range of nonmotor symptoms, including some features commonly associated with AD, such as mild cognitive impairment that frequently progresses to dementia [ 2]. In addition to Lewy body pathology, typical AD related morphological changes, including amyloid-beta (A β) pathology, have been proposed to be involved in the pathogenesis of PD dementia. This is reinforced by neuroimaging studies using PET, and with the strong inverse association between A β load at autopsy and time to dementia in PD [ 3, 4].
